awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Accretion Revelations from Changing-Look Quasars
awd_abstract_narration:
Quasars are brilliant but tiny emitters of light.  Being so tiny, it is hard to fathom how they work.  Astronomers suspect the brilliance is caused by gas flooding toward a massive black hole.  Curiously, a few, rare quasars have dramatically dimmed.  These are the changing-look quasars (CLQs), and they offer clues about how the floodgates can close.  The team will use optical observations to find more CLQs and study their details.  Senior team members will train junior team members from underrepresented groups.  The team will convert their light-based data to sound so that they can share their research with the blind or visually impaired.

The team will (1) conduct archival and directed searches in multi-epoch SDSS optical spectra, to produce a large and well-defined statistical sample of new CLQs, (2) select new CLQ candidates for spectroscopic follow-up based on dramatic variability observed in their photometric light curves, and (3) investigate the spectroscopic and photometric variability properties of this sample of at least about 80 CLQs, to characterize and understand the phenomenon.

por.por_cntn:
The recent (essentially just since 2015) discovery of the first changing-look quasars (CLQs) in which luminous quasars dim dramatically to a quiescent galaxy-like state in repeat optical spectra over <10 year timescales, provides an exciting new probe of the structure of quasar accretion disks and their nuclear environments. This research program helped to identify a larger sample (vs. the ~15 known at the start of this program) of new CLQs, and to characterize their properties. We accomplished archival and directed searches in multi-epoch Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), and other-observatory follow up optical spectra, to produce a larger and better-defined statistical sample of new CLQs; we selected new CLQ candidates for spectroscopic follow-up based on variability observed in their photometric light curves; and we investigated the spectroscopic/photometric variability and multi-wavelength properties of this sample to understand the dramatic spectral changes of CLQs. This specific summary is naturally weighted toward the University of Washington (UW), though as a collaborative program we also are closely connected in our joint progress to the work of our colleague Dr. Paul Green and others at the Harvard/Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO).

CLQs provide a unique and unexpected opportunity to directly probe the structure of accretion disks and the gaseous environment around active supermassive black holes on human timescales. Their study challenges and potentially resolves the current tension between observational inferences of quasar accretion disk structure and theoretical models, while also testing and informing the decades-long debate about unification of active galactic nuclei subtypes.

Both undergraduate (>10) and graduate students (2) have been involved in aspects of this program at UW, in both the research itself and extending to preparation of science presentations and papers. For example, one former graduate student, Dr. John Ruan finished his PhD at UW and after a prize postdoctoral fellowship at McGill University, started as an assistant professor at Bishop's University in 2020, and remains a leader in CLQ studies (and multi-messenger studies). Involving undergraduate students directly in research is a key aim of the Astronomy Department for its majors at the UW. Among the more than 10 UW undergraduates involved with Anderson in looking at ~10^4 multi-epoch spectra for CLQs, many students have now completed their Bachelor's degrees at UW, including five of whom (thus far) have gone on to graduate school programs elsewhere, including three thus far in astronomy. Among these undergraduates about half were from groups typically under-represented in the physical sciences.

Similarly, former postdoctoral fellow Dr. Chelsea MacLeod (now in spacebased industry employment), and post-baccalaureate staff working with Dr. Paul Green at SAO completed extensive additional, and complementary CLQ work, verifying CLQ candidates from imaging photometric variability, the SDSS spectroscopic archive, and optical spectroscopy and photometry using various other telescopes (also including the MMT, Magellan, Gemini, and Mt. Hopkins facilities). They were among the leading/main authors on recent resulting CLQ publications.

In total this program found more than 30 new strong and quantitatively  confirmed CLQs, a very substantive advance in sample size vs. the ~15 total published at the start of this program.  The program as a whole includes nearly a dozen conference proceedings/presentations as worked progressed, but the underlying selections and new discoveries or confirmations are most extensively detailed in:

*MacLeod, Chelsea L., Green, Paul J., Anderson, Scott F. et al. 2018, Astronomical Journal, 155, 6. "The Time-domain Spectroscopic Survey: Target Selection for Repeat Spectroscopy"

*MacLeod, Chelsea, L., Green, Paul J., Anderson, Scott F. et al. 2019, Astrophysical Journal, 874, 8. "Changing-look Quasar Candidates: First Results from Follow-up Spectroscopy of Highly Optically Variable Quasars"

*Green, Paul, J., Pulgarin-Duque, Lina, Anderson, Scott F. et al. 2021 submitted for SDSS internal review (internal review, just prior to anticipated submission to s journal). "The Time Domain Spectroscopic Survey: Changing-Look Quasar Candidates from Multi-Epoch Spectroscopy in SDSS-IV"

In addition, under this program we made substantial advances with multiwavelength follow-up (e.g., X-ray, host-galaxy studies from groundbased observatorites, etc.) observations of CLQs we confirmed. A major advance  here is further verifification of intriguing connections (based on combined X-ray and optical studies) between accretion transitions in distant supermassive black holes of quasars and stellar-mass black holes in nearby Galactic compact binaries. Especially, we note in this context two recent refereed publications:

*Ruan, John J., Anderson, Scott F., Eracleous, Mike. et al. 2019, Astrophysical Journal, 883 76. "The Analogous Structure of Accretion Flows in Supermassive and Stellar Mass Black Holes: New Insights from  Faded Changing-look Quasars"

*Jin, X., Ruan, John J., Haggard, D. et al. 2021, Astrophysical Journal, 912, 20. "Probing the Disk-Corona Systems and Broad-line Regions of Changing-look Quasars with X-Ray and Optical Observations"

In closing, we wish to express our many thanks for the superb support from NSF for this program, including through unusually difficult and unanticipated times.
